Original example: The emergency declaration will ``recognize the severity of our crisis and break new ground to maximize our ability to urgently move people inside, and do so for good. Sunday's ceremony was initially scheduled to take place outside City Hall, but rain in the forecast led to a venue shift indoors. Surprise performers at the inauguration included Stevie Wonder, who sang ``Keep Our Love Alive'' and ``Living for the City,'' and Chloe Bailey and Las Cafeteras. Amanda Gorman, the first National Youth Poet Laureate, who also delivered a poem at President Joe Biden's inauguration, said in her reading Sunday that ``the time of never before is officially past.'' Bass' father fled the Jim Crow south during the great African American migration after World War II and found work as a letter carrier. ``When I think about the dreams of working people today, I reflect on the fact that my mother and father were able to buy a home in Los Angeles for their family of six with one paycheck,'' Bass said. Bass' organizing career began in 1990 when she founded Community Coalition, a South Los Angeles social justice group in response to the crack cocaine crisis. State Senate President pro-Tempore Toni Atkins said that Bass didn't run for mayor for ``credit or photo-opps.''Kamala Harris to swear in Karen Bass as first female mayor of Los Angeles Vice President Kamala Harris will swear in Karen Bass as the 43rd mayor of Los Angeles in an inauguration ceremony on Sunday in a meeting of two Democratic women who have broken barriers in politics. Bass alluded to her history of firsts shortly after winning her race when she told reporters that the accomplishment of becoming the first female mayor of Los Angeles was still “sinking in.” “When you’re in a position like this – and I was in a similar position when I was sworn in as speaker – it means that you have extra responsibility. “The path that you go is laying the foundation for those that come behind you.” After her victory, Bass promised to solve the homelessness crisis in the nation’s second-largest city. “She is holding her inaugural ceremony on Sunday to make it easier for Angelenos to attend and to ensure her first day as mayor is dedicated to bringing unhoused Angelenos inside and making our city safer and more livable for all,” the mayor-elect’s office said in a statement announcing the ceremony. The six-term congresswoman, who currently represents South and West Los Angeles, defeated real estate developer Rick Caruso in the general election last month. During her campaign, Bass leaned into her experience bringing together Black and Latino community organizers in South Los Angeles in the early 1990s to address the root causes of crime and the crack epidemic. She was able to put together a winning coalition of Black voters in South Los Angeles and White progressives on the city’s west side to help overcome Caruso’s spending. The mayor-elect began her career as a physician assistant in the emergency room in Los Angeles County.The ceremony was initially scheduled to take place outside of City Hall, but due to the rain, was moved indoors. Ready to get down to business, Bass said she would spend her first day in office declaring a state of emergency on the homeless issue plaguing the city. "I will start my first day as mayor at the city's emergency operations centers, where my first act as mayor will be to declare a state of emergency on homelessness," Bass said, noting that she will "recognize the severity of our crisis and break new ground to maximize our ability to urgently move people inside, and do so for good." Dozens of prominent politicians were in attendance for the inauguration, including California State Senate President pro-tempore Toni Atkins, Los Angeles County Democratic Party Chairman Mark Gonzalez and Governor Gavin Newsom. Bass, 69, was a social worker and community activist before representing Los Angeles in the state Assembly for six years, where she also served as the first African American speaker. Council President Paul Krekorian spoke at the event, predicting that Bass is just the leader the city of Los Angeles needs to bring people together. He now awaits further plans pending his nomination to become U.S. ambassador to India, which has hit a snag due to opposition from some on Senate, concerned with sexual misconduct allegations against a former Garcetti staff member. Bass was named mayor-elect in November after a close race with her competitor Rick Caruso, the billionaire developer who spent more than $100 million on his campaign.

Begin story::

Vice President Kamala Harris will swear in Karen Bass as the 43rd mayor of Los Angeles in an inauguration ceremony on Sunday, meeting two Democratic women who have broken barriers in politics. The ceremony, which was slated to take place outdoors at City Hall, was moved indoors due to rain in the forecast. Numerous prominent politicians were in attendance, including California State Senate President pro-tempore Toni Atkins, Los Angeles County Democratic Party Chairman Mark Gonzalez, and Governor Gavin Newsom. 

Bass, a 69 year old social worker, the first African-American woman to hold the office, garnered a considerable victory over billionaire developer Rick Caruso in the Nov. 8 general election. She promised to address the city's housing crisis, and declared her first official act as mayor to be a state of emergency on homelessness.

Originally beginning as a physician assistant at Los Angeles County in 1990, Bass founded Community Coalition, a South Los Angeles social justice group, in response to the crack cocaine epidemic. She entered the legislature in 2004 and became the first African-American woman to become Assembly Speaker in the seventh state in the nation three years later in 2008. 

Prior to her mayoral campaign, Bass had served on the U.S. House for five years and the Congressional Black Caucus for nearly a decade. During her campaign, she leaned into her experience with uniting Black and Latino community organizers and procuring 17,000 volunteers — including thousands of new voters. 

At the inauguration, Bass spoke about what the moment meant for her and the people of South Los Angeles. Her father had fled the Jim Crow south during the great African-American migration after World War II and found work as a letter carrier. Bass continued, “When I think about the dreams of working people today, I reflect on the fact that my mother and father were able to buy a home in Los Angeles for their family of six with one paycheck”.

Council President Paul Krekorian spoke at the event, predicting that Bass is just the leader the city of Los Angeles needs to bring people together. To commemorate the occasion, surprise performers included music virtuoso Stevie Wonder, Chloe Bailey and Las Cafeteras. National Youth Poet Laureate Amanda Gorman, who also delivered a poem at President Joe Biden's inauguration earlier this year, read her poem “The Time of Never Before is Officially Past.”

The ceremony marked a significant moment for Bass, who noted to reporters after winning her race that the gravity of becoming the first female mayor of Los Angeles was only beginning to sink in. “When you’re in a position like this – and I was in a similar position when I was sworn in as speaker – it means that you have extra responsibility. The path that you go is laying the foundation for those that come behind you.” 

State Senate President pro-Tempore Toni Atkins spoke at the event, noting that Bass didn't run for mayor for "credit or photo-opps,” instead understanding the gravity of her role in developing the city of Los Angeles. Bass, who is expected to serve through 2022, is now held to the promise of treating the homelessness crisis while concurrently driving the economy of the city.

Begin story::

Amanda Gorman, the first National Youth Poet Laureate, shared her inspirational words during the inauguration of Los Angeles Mayor-elect, City Councilor, 69-year-old Nury Martinez on Sunday, November 14, 2021. The ceremony was initially scheduled to take place outside of City Hall, but was moved indoors due to the rain. Gorman said in her reading that "the time of never before is officially past" as dozens of prominent politicians, like California State Senate President pro-tempore Toni Atkins, LA County Democratic Party Chairman Mark Gonzalez and Governor Gavin Newsom, attended the inauguration.

Martinez, a social worker and community activist, began her career as a physician assistant in the emergency room of Los Angeles County and served in the state assembly for six years, during which she was the first African American speaker of the house. In 1990, she founded Community Coalition, a South Los Angeles social justice group that sought to address the root causes of crime and the crack cocaine epidemic in response to the crisis.

Martinez's father had earlier fled the Jim Crow south during the great African American migration following World War II and worked as a letter carrier. Her campaign during the mayoral election leaned into her experience of bringing together Black and Latino community organizers in South Los Angeles in the early 1990s. The inauguration followed her 2021 electoral victory over rival candidate and former LA City Councilman Paul Krekorian in November 8, 2019.

During her inaugural speech, Martinez thanked all angelenos for their "work towards creating a city where all of our children can thrive no matter what zip code they call home". She also named prominent activists and visionaries, like Robert F. Kennedy's "Children of the Dream" speech of 1968 and Stevie Wonder's Living for the City, who are living legacies of hardworking communities.

In attendance of Martinez's swearing-in ceremony were over 17,000 residents, 80 members of the Congressional Black Caucus, and several household names, including professional dancers Chloe and Halle Bailey who perform the song Keep Our Love. Other attending guests included Los Angeles County Democratic Party chairman Mark Gonzalez and Rick Caruso, a businessman and Los Angeles Community College community member.

The inauguration ceremony was held at the Microsoft Theater and streamed live, where it was watched by over 175,000 viewers. The inaugural committee also distributed 3,500 tote bags with Martinez's slogan "L.A. is Here" printed on them. Martinez is the second Latinx mayor of Los Angeles and her first four year term, starting from 2021 to 2022, will see her make hard decisions with the City Council, who must manage the city's budget of nearly 40,000 every month.

Martinez's inauguration also coincided with the nomination of Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti for the US Ambassador to India, a decision that has been met by opposition from some members of the Senate due to sexual misconduct allegations against a former Garcetti staff member.
